question: Surface antigen of E coli acting as virulence factors are:-
exp: Virulence factors of E. coli: Surface antigens Toxins Somatic or O ag- Lipopolysaccharide (LPS), most impoant virulence factor & responsible for endotoxic activities LT (heat labile toxin) - - | c. AMP so causes excessive secretion of Na/Cl/H2O from within to outside the cell = secretory diarrhea Flagellar or H Ag- Makes the bacteria motile. ST (heat stable toxin)- - | c. GMP so fluid accumulation in gut = Diarrhea Capsular or K Ag- It is a polysaccharide capsular Ag, inhibits the phagocytosis. Verocytotoxin or Shiga like toxin - - It inhibits the protein synthesis by binding to 28S subunit of 60S ribosome = Cell death Fimbrial antigen (Pilus) - helps in attachment & colonization.

question: Stain for treponema -
exp: Option 1 Microscopy: Silver impregnation method: (i) Levaditi stain (for tissue section): corkscrew shaped Treponema pallidum (ii). Fontana stain(smear)- showing the spiral morphology Option 2 Acid-fast stain is used for stain acid fast organism (Mycobacterium) or structures (Endospore). Option 3 Gomori Methenamine-Silver (GMS) stain: for fungal organisms. Option 4 Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) is a staining method used to detect polysaccharides such as glycogen, and mucosubstances such as glycoproteins, glycolipids and mucins in tissues.

question: All of the following are true about Methicillin resistance in MRSA, except-
exp: Resistance in MRSA is chromosomally mediated (not plasmid mediated). Resistance is produced as a result of altered PBP's- mediated chromosomal mec A gene which codes for altered PBP- 2A. Resistance may be produced by hyperproduction of beta-lactamase Methicillin resistance is expressed more at 30degC than at 37degC. Therefore, resistance may be missed at incubation temperature at 37degC during susceptibility testing.
opa: Resistance is produced as a result of altered PBP's
opb: Resistance may be produced by hyperproduction of beta lactamase
opd: Resistance may be missed at incubation temperature of 370C during susceptibility testing

question: Which of the following test is the best diagnosis in a patient with typhoid?
exp: Other than a positive blood culture, no specific laboratory test is diagnostic for enteric fever. Option 2- The possible presence of cross reactive antibodies limits the use of serological test in the diagnosis of Salmonella. Option 3, 4: Stool/Urine culture can be used for typhoid carriers.

question: CLED agar is preferred to Mac. Conkey in the processing of urinary samples because:
exp: CLED (Cysteine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium Non-selective medium on which both Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria can grow. Mac. Conkey Mildly selective medium for Gram negative. Most Gram positive is inhibited. CLED agar is hence preferred over Mac. Conkey in the processing of urinary samples. Both media inhibit swarming of Proteus. Since both contain lactose, both are differential media, i. e-LF and NLF can be differentiated.
opa: It suppos both Gram positive and Gram negative organisms
opc: The growth can be seen in 4 hours
opd: Klebsiella and E. coli can be differentiated easily

question: Diagnostic method of choice for leptospirosis:
exp: Cold agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae Microscopic agglutination test- Leptospira Latex agglutination test can be used to identify and type several organisms The microscopic agglutination test (MAT) is the gold standard for sero-diagnosis of leptospirosis because of its unsurpassed diagnostic specificity. It uses panels of live leptospires, ideally recent isolates, representing the circulating serovars from the area where the patient became infected.

question: Diagnostic test of choice for neurosyphilis is:-
exp: VDRL CSF test is the standard serological test for CSF and it is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis VDRL: Quantitation of the sera is useful to monitor activity of the disease and is of prognostic value. The RPR test is used for testing serum or plasma, but not for the CSF.

question: Catalase positive, coagulase negative beta hemolytic bacteria
exp: All staphylococci are catalase positive. Amongst staphylococci, Staph. aureus and Staph haemolyticus (CONS) are beta hemolytic. Most species of coagulase negative staphylococcus species are non-hemolytic except Staph. haemolyticus.

question: In which of the following ways is CLED medium better than Mc. Conkey agar for UTI (AIIMS NOV. 2020)
exp: CLED ( Cysteine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient Media )- Inhibits growth of other commensals & allows staphylococcus and Candida to grow. It enhaces the growth of dwarf colonies of coliforms d/t presence of cysteine Mc. Conkey and CLED both prevent swarming of Proteus and differentiate between LF and NLF. Gram positive organisms usually can't grow in Mc. Conkey, it is selective for gram negative organisms.
opa: It differentiates lactose fermenters from Non-fermenters
opd: It allows staphylococcus and Candida to grow
